title: Finance and Cash Management for Hospitality
headline: Learn how to manage costs and other financial commitments in the hospitality business with this free online course.
description: This course helps you build competencies in financial and cost management for the hospitality and travel industries. You will learn why a budget plan is necessary for businesses such as restaurants and hotels, and what factors to consider. Finally, the course provides you with hands-on lessons on efficiently drawing up budgets using spreadsheets for the different operational aspects of running a successful and profitable hospitality business.

courseDescription:
This course is designed to help you develop the ability to manage costs and other financial commitments in hospitality businesses. It begins with an introduction to the concepts and systems of cost management. During low business periods, businesses are expected to adjust. This course explains why you need to make these adjustments and how to do them effectively so that you can navigate quiet periods financially. The material explores zero-based budgeting (ZBB) extensively. It articulates the key factors to consider within the structure of the business to apply this budgeting system effectively. You will learn also about the ABC (activity-based costing) system of cost management as well as different energy-saving techniques that can be employed.

The second part provides you with detailed lessons on how to draw up effective budgets across different operations. You will be shown how to structure a room-revenue budget plan and how to calculate the revenue generated from rooms. You will then learn about the F&B (food and beverage) revenue budget plan and the factors to consider when creating one. Except for a few differences, the banquet budget is often considered very similar to the F&B plan. Do you know what these differences are? Other hospitality budgeting operations detailed include headcount and payroll, as well as other miscellaneous sections crucial to running a hospitality business. Finally, the course teaches you how to evaluate cash flow within the business structure.

The Covid pandemic saw a lot of businesses in the hospitality sector shut down over the last few years, only to have to reopen. A key reality is the nature in which reopening should occur to avoid financial troubles. To do this, the financial manager must be able to realign and adjust the companyâ€™s resources to suit the reality of the business at the time. This course helps build the acumen of a financial manager in hospitality by factoring in the plethora of variables that can affect cost and finances within the company. The lessons on budgeting are carefully illustrated with a number of Excel templates. You will be taught how to efficiently evaluate costs and draft budgets for practically every operation in a hotel during a period of low demand or activity. If you are a hospitality student, work in tourism or want to brush your knowledge on budgeting for the travel industry, sign up for free now.

Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:

Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital certificate: a downloadable certificate in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

  • Module Lesson Summary

  • The uncertain future means that the business will need cash to navigate difficult times. Cash flow planning is needed because it will help identify opportunities:
    • For alternative revenue streams.
    • For cost management using technology.
    • For business consolidations.
    • Reaching out to partners.
  • Some of the things to note before and while conducting the cash flow planning:
  • Past actual trends
    • Occupancy (preferable by market segments).
    • Guests (Nationality and booking source)
    • Effectiveness of distribution channels.
    • F&B covers and their relationship to in-house guests and outside covers.
    • Spa guests and its relationship with in-house guests and outside guests.

  • Module Lesson Summary

  • In drafting a budget the first thing that must be done is to establish the past strengths and existing figures to ascertain the business' performance.
  • Although using previous records may help predict trends in some aspects of hotel operations like room night bookings, you should also factor in possible variables like global trends or pandemics that can derail the trends.
  • F&B revenue (food and beverage revenue) is dependent on the in-house guests and the number of outside guests that a hotel is able to get over the period in focus.
  • Banquet budgets share a similar template as F&B budgets. The only difference between both is that banquet budgets do not contain covers.  The following are segments in a banquet budget:
    • Corporate meetings
    • Social functions.
    • Government functions.
    • Others
